segments.text: For over two months, Leora secretly slipped away every weekend to her pink house, settling into the room she declared her own.
Slowly, the house returned to its original shape, clean, tidy, and polished.
On the tables near the bar, she spread tablecloths and placed small vases of wildflowers, which she replaced weekly upon arrival.
However, the main change was evident in the garden, which gradually recovered and healed from the neglect it had suffered.
The weekly watering revived the grass, turning it green again, and all the plants that had wilted began to stand tall once more, reaching for the sun.
One weekend after beginning her officer's course, she got off at the nursery stop, one before the pink houses.
Shraga, the lanky man responsible for the nursery, and once her agriculture teacher, greeted her with a large, surprised smile.
Shraga had a unique blend of red hair, height, and gangliness.
She always thought his height was meant to house his large, tender heart.
She once read about the concept of a giraffe's heart, referring to people with big, generous hearts, like a giraffe's, which carries the largest heart in nature.
Shraga had such a heart, kind and sensitive even to the plants around him.
Hi, Shraga, how are you?
She greeted cheerfully.
I'd like trays of pansies, silver baskets, and maybe some lupins if you have any, those that are the cheapest because I don't have too much money to spend on them.
He looked at her affectionately.
Come, I'll give you some of the smaller plastic ones that seem less impressive now.
But they'll grow wonderfully, just wait.
For a moment she thought it was just like life.
Sometimes those that seem less impressive grow wonderfully.
They walked leisurely along the path, damp from watering, stopping at wooden pallets, holding small plastic cups from which sprouted newly emerged flowers.
Shraga reached out with veined hands and rolled up sleeves, filling two cardboard lids with pansies, silver baskets, snapdragons, and lupins.
Perhaps he'd like to take some sweet peas too, he quietly suggested, raising his eyes.
They're just beginning now, and you'll have two months of stunning blooms around the house walls.
It's hard to imagine the pink house without sweet peas at the start of winter.
Lucy attended to it diligently, and it was beautiful to see how all the pink and purple blended so well with the pink walls.
He fell silent, fearing he might hurt her with memories.
She looked up at him with an embracing gaze.
This tall man's sensitivity truly encompassed everything.
An awkward man with unruly ginger hair and soft eyes.
which is why he did not remain long as an agriculture teacher.
Some of the children teased him and made fun of him.
Children can be cruel, but he found his calling in gardening and maintaining the nursery, which became his passion.
I'd love to take some sweet peas too, but I worry I'll need your help with tying the strings they can climb on.
My father used to help my mother with those, she smiled.
I'd be happy to help.
I'll stop by next weekend or in two weeks.
No rush.
It'll take a bit before they start to climb.
He couldn't understand why Joseph couldn't help her as usual.
For hours on her knees, she planted the flower seedlings, creating a long trench along the house walls.
carefully placing sweet pea seeds, seed after seed, ensuring spaces between them, just as she remembered from Lucy.
Her fingers filled with mud as she dug trench after trench, arranging the seeds in a line.
Suddenly, while digging, her fingers hit something metallic.
She dug a bit more and from the mud emerged a large square ring.

Shocked, she held it in her trembling hands, wiped off the mud, got to her feet with shaky knees, and washed it under the tap, rubbing it over and over until it gleamed and its reddish gold color was revealed again.
For a moment, she wanted to scream to the heavens so her mother would hear and know she found her ring.
But she only sat down exhausted.
clutching the ring tightly in her fist, closing her eyes, and picturing the moment the ring was lost.
Every year, up to that fateful one when it happened, as winter approached.
And it was getting cold, Lucy would begin her sweet pea operation.

She'd pull from the drawer her golden metal box, where she kept the sweet pea seeds collected from the previous season's pods, transferring them to a jar half full of water and soaking them overnight.
This enhances germination after planting," she'd explain.
On Operation Day, she'd water the narrow trench Joseph had dug the day before along the house walls.
And only after straining the seeds from the water, she'd move to planting.
She would take a few seeds in her hand and sprinkle them gently along the wall, taking small steps as she went.
Each time, she'd buried a handful of seeds until she was done.
Then she'd kneel covering the seeds with mounds of moist earth,
piled along the dug trench and gently pat them down.
Daily watering was needed to keep the soil moist for the sweet peas to sprout.
Here Joseph would join in.
He drove nails into the walls in rows, 20, 30 and 40 centimeters high, tying and stretching twine between them to create a lattice.
When the stems grew and the flowers bloomed, they would attach to the strings and remain upright.
So much work for two months of bloom.
Joseph would laugh lovingly.
In the winter months, after the fall holidays, the pink house slowed down.
It no longer hosted dozens of people from dawn until night, only a few regular residents working nearby who posed little demand during the day.
They'd leave in the morning and return in the evening.
Thus winter became a time for rest and pleasure, reading, knitting, and repainting everything faded.
Joseph would occasionally take out his easel and paint with his watercolors and oils, and Lucy found more time to tend to her beloved garden.

When the sweet peas began to bloom, Lucy would excitedly call Joseph to come and see, and they would stand together admiring the wonder, enveloping the house's walls with pastel pink and purple, like a colorful scarf.
Sometimes she'd go out to remove wilted leaves to boost and prolong the bloom, and other times she picked small bouquets for vases on dining tables.
One could really feel how much joy and happiness she derived from tending the sweet peas each year, until the winter it happened.
Lucy wore a special ring on her right hand's ring finger.
A large, square gold ring, slightly bulky, the type usually worn by men.
Its top could be opened, and inside was affixed an image of a man, so small it was nearly indiscernible.
Over the years, opening it had become tricky, but she never took off that ring.
Leora was too young to understand the ring's significance or the man within, and no one took the time to explain.
To her, he was the man in the ring.
That year, when Lucy finished sowing the seeds and smoothing the moist earth over them, she was shocked to find the ring missing from her hand.
The wet mud had likely caused the ring to slip off, swallowed by the soil during planting.
She cried out for Joseph, who rushed over, alarmed, not understanding what had happened.
The ring, I lost my ring, I must find it, she cried, tears in her eyes.
Only he knew what it meant to her.

He immediately called over the three house workers who were busy painting, and everyone, the workers, Joseph, Lucy, and little Leora, crouched, pouring over the long-seated trench around the house, turning the moist earth again and again, searching near and around the bed until they realized the ring was swallowed by the earth.
Lucy sat on the ground, limbs limp, legs stretched forward, silently crying real tears down her cheeks.
Helpless, Joseph stroked her head, knowing he couldn't console her.
Leora had never seen her mother cry before and was shaken by it, her heart going out to her.
In the innocence and good intentions of a twelve-year-old, she said, It's okay, mom, don't cry.
Daddy will buy you a new ring.
Lucy lifted her head as if seeing her for the first time, looking at her with deep pain and said in a choked voice, No, sweetheart, a ring like that daddy can't buy me.
Sometimes even children have deep understanding because of the man in the ring.
Leora asked.
Yes, Lucy whispered because of the man in the ring.
Only years later did she understand the ring was all that remained of Abraham, her husband, murdered by Arab rioters from Jaffa, just two weeks after they married.
She opened her eyes and slowly released her clenched fist, gazing in wonder at the ring resting quietly in her palm.
For years it hid deep in the ground, and now it seemed as if Lucy directed her to find it.
She understood she didn't need to shout.
She knew Lucy was watching from above.
Seeing the ring found, finally finding rest.
The following weekend, she was on base.
Otherwise, she would have been almost happy about it, but suddenly she longed greatly for her home.
She fully understood it wasn't truly hers, that she was creating a temporary illusion bubble to live in.
But despite the loneliness, it was so pleasant and good whenever she came there.
She met no people, not even friends, except Albert from the grocery, and Carmella, the neighbor, whose window faces her kitchen window.
She always knew when she left and when she returned, and through the windows they could hear each other's music and delight in it.

A week later, when she arrived for the weekend, she immediately noticed the nails hammered along the walls and the cotton twine stretched between them in a lattice, allowing the sweet peas to climb and bloom on the house walls.
She understood right away that Sraga had visited the place when she wasn't there, seizing the opportunity to water the garden as well.
She was so happy.
After she finished cleaning the house, putting something on the stove, and turning on the sprinklers, she made her way to the nursery, covering the 300 meters separating them on foot.
People wandered between the nursery paths, trying to decide what to choose.
She noticed Shraga bent over pots with a watering can in hand, and she walked towards him energetically and joyfully.
Only when standing very close did he notice her presence, jumping in surprise.
I came to say thank you.
There's no one like you, Shraga.
It's a shame I wasn't there when you came.
But now I want to invite you for coffee, or if you agree, even for dinner.
It was really no problem, no need to make a fuss.
I was happy to help," he replied bashfully.
Maybe I'll stop by some time to make sure everything's okay.
He hesitated with the words, as if trying to give his tone a casual note.
But she saw he felt uncomfortable and decided to let go.
All right, Shraga, come whenever you want.
You're always welcome," she laughed.
Just remember I mostly come on weekends, sometimes as early as Thursday like today.
She waved goodbye and left.
Shraga watched her receding form.
It turned out there was a complete gap in his information about what had happened with the pink house.
He didn't know it was sold, didn't know it was neglected for many months, and didn't know the girl had secretly returned to reside in one of its rooms.
He wasn't the sociable type.
Plants were his main companions, meeting people only when they came to the nursery, where most of his conversations focused on plant types, how to grow them, and what to plant when and where.
A week earlier, when he arrived at the pink house, he was surprised to see everything closed and really didn't understand what had happened there.
But a promise is a promise, and he began hammering nails parallel to the seeds that had sprouted.
Carmella the neighbor heard the noise and came over.
From her, he heard in five minutes the gist of all that had happened with that house in the long months of the test year.
His heart broke for the girl and all she'd gone through.
And he was so glad in her joy that she returned there and made herself a corner, ensuring it was blooming and green as her mother loved.
He remembered how, when Lucy was still alive, he'd occasionally come to help her cultivate the garden.
Her hand was in every plant she grew, but the sweet peas were her cherished delight.
He recalled how she'd collect the seeds from the pods at Bloom's End
and replant them every autumn as winter approached.
The sweet peabushes wrapped the house like a pink and purple gown each winter beginning, and they were a significant part of the house's scenery.
It was hard not to.
Field the house wilted with her passing, and he was so happy with its revitalization, but he was shy and embarrassed and knew he wouldn't go to drink or eat with her.
only visit sometimes to ensure everything was watered and blooming properly, making sure nothing wilted while she was in the Army.
